item.description:
Heart-pounding video captures the moment a hero NYPD detective on the way to work saved a choking baby on the side of a highway in the middle of rush-hour traffic.

Det. First Grade Michael Greaney, who works in the office of Chief of Detectives Joseph Kenny, was heading to the office around 8:45 a.m. Wednesday when he spotted a black BMW speeding along the emergency shoulder lane of the southbound Bronx River Parkway, cops said.

Greaney, who was driving an unmarked truck, flicked his lights on and pulled over to see what was going on, according to cops and the footage, which was posted to TikTok.

The driver turned out to be a panic-stricken dad who told the detective, ‚ÄúMy baby‚Äôs choking,‚Äù police said.
Greaney reached into the car, picked up the pint-sized girl wearing a pink onesie, and repeatedly banged on her back while holding her on the side of the road.

The tot‚Äôs throat was quickly cleared and she started to breathe again, authorities said.

A good Samaritan pediatrician spotted the commotion, checked on the baby and confirmed she was OK, police said.

The dad drove off and later confirmed to police that the baby girl was doing well.

Greaney is a 17-year department veteran who joined the NYPD in July of 2008, records show.
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.description:
The New Jersey State Police‚Äôs second-in-command, who was accused of making an antisemitic remark at a children‚Äôs event, will hit the road by the time Mikie Sherrill becomes governor next month, The Post has learned.

Lt. Col. Sean Kilcomons is set to leave the force by the start of the year, along with NJSP Superintendent Patrick Callahan, sources and officials said this week.

Kilcomons faced a firestorm last year when an internal complaint accused the high-ranking police official of spewing an offensive comment directed at state Attorney General Matt Platkin, who is Jewish, during a ‚ÄúBring Your Child to Work Day‚Äù event on April 25, 2024.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want that Jew‚Äôs kid in the State Police helicopter,‚Äù Kilcomons allegedly said in reference to Platkin and his son possibly looking inside a department chopper during the event, according to a report lodged with the¬†AG‚Äôs Public Integrity and Accountability Unit, The Post reported last fall.

An investigation was launched into the allegations, and an attorney general spokesperson said Wednesday there was no update on the probe.

A source said Kilcomons is going to retire as Sherrill, a Democratic former congresswoman, isn‚Äôt interested in keeping him on.

The NJSP didn‚Äôt return a request for comment.

When asked whether Sherrill had any interest in keeping Callahan or Kilcomons on the force, her transition team referred The Post to an X post she sent out Monday calling Callahan‚Äôs service ‚Äúcommendable‚Äù and wishing him well in retirement.

Callahan announced Monday he was retiring and would¬†‚Äúnot be renominated by the incoming administration,‚Äù according to a press release issued by term-limited Gov. Phil Murphy.

In a letter sent to the department before the announcement and obtained by The Post, Callahan told troopers that serving as head of the agency ‚Äúhas been the highest honor of my life.‚Äù

But the agency has been roiled in turmoil, including black activists calling on Murphy to oust both Callahan and Kilcomons.

Bishop Jethro James, a state police chaplain, slammed Kilcomons as a ‚Äúracist‚Äù and told The Post this week that his exit ‚Äúis a long time coming.‚Äù

James said that while the department could face legal liability in part over Kilcomons‚Äô alleged actions during his tenure, he insisted ‚Äúat least he will no longer have any say in the day-to-day operations of New Jersey state troopers and for that I am grateful.‚Äù

Two probes released by the Attorney General‚Äôs Office last year found ‚Äúdeeply troubling and systemic problems‚Äù in the police force,¬†including alleged discrimination and weaponizing internal affairs against some troopers.

The department is also facing a misconduct investigation after troopers issued fewer traffic tickets following a report alleging racial disparities among those hit with traffic infractions, according to the New York Times, citing court docs and people familiar with the proceedings.

The enforcement slowdown stretched between July 2023 and March 2024, the Times reported.

A union representing state police supervisors argued in a court filing that the traffic report warned every trooper that any stop could be a possibly unconstitutional act, the Times reported.

That fear led union leaders to warn troopers about the ‚Äúperils of motor vehicle stops,‚Äù according to the filing, though a Callahan spokesperson told the newspaper he did not endorse a wind-down in traffic enforcement.¬†
item.author: Larry Celona, Craig McCarthy, David Propper

item.title: Lindsay LohanÁöÑÂÖÑÂºüÂõ†Ê∂âÂ´åÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈùûÊ≥ïÂ§öÊî∂ÁßüÈáëËÄåË¢´Ëµ∑ËØâ
item.description:
Lindsay Lohan‚Äôs younger brother, Michael Lohan Jr., is being sued for allegedly cashing in on the Big Apple real estate market by illegally deregulating more than 150 rent-stabilized apartments, state Attorney General Letitia James said.

The Hollywood star‚Äôs sibling is among a handful of property honchos from Peak Capital Advisors that were involved in an alleged scheme to oust tenants in rent-stabilized apartments in Brooklyn and Queens so they could renovate the buildings into luxury lofts and market them to young professionals for upwards of $6,500 per month in some cases, according to the lawsuit.

The suit, filed last week, alleges that the real estate development company‚Äôs bigwigs bought up 31 buildings across the two boroughs dating back to 2019 ‚Äî including in trendy neighborhoods like Greenpoint and Williamsburg.

They then converted 159 rent-stabilized apartments in those buildings to market-rate so they could overcharge tenants scrambling to live in those areas, court filings allege.

‚ÄúPeak‚Äôs business plan from the outset was to market the apartments to young professionals willing to pay high rents without regard for rent stabilization laws,‚Äù the suit states.

‚ÄúPeak specifically looked for buildings with ‚Äòsignificant upside potential‚Äô in gentrifying neighborhoods such as Sunnyside, Astoria, Long Island City, and Greenpoint.‚Äù

As part of the alleged scheme, Lohan and his co-accused exploited an exemption in state housing law that aims to incentivize the rehabilitation of seriously deteriorated buildings.

‚ÄúPeak ignored the law and renovated solely to increase its profits,‚Äù the lawsuit charges.

‚ÄúRecords clearly show that Peak‚Äôs buildings did not require extensive renovations to be habitable, as they were in average or good condition when Peak bought them. Therefore, Peak did not meet the legal requirement for deregulation.‚Äù

Once the renovations were complete, they allegedly tried to cover their tracks by reassigning apartment numbers in the building to make it harder for tenants and regulators to track whether the rent was actually legal.

Lohan, who is listed as a principal and head of Peak‚Äôs investor relations, received rent or was entitled to receive rent from the properties, the lawsuit claims, noting that he ‚Äúpersonally received unlawful monetary gains.‚Äù

The suit, brought jointly by the AG‚Äôs office and the state‚Äôs Homes and Community Renewal commission, is asking for the overcharged rent to be paid back, as well as damages for the tenants.

‚ÄúIt is no secret that New York City is already battling an affordable housing crisis, and yet Peak and its operators still chose to line their own pockets at New Yorkers‚Äô expense,‚Äù James said in a statement.

‚ÄúAs these bad actors illegally raked in profits, affordable housing in New York grew even more scarce, and that is unacceptable. Let this lawsuit be a warning: when corporate developers and bad landlords try to cheat housing laws, my office will always take aggressive action to stop them.‚Äù

The others listed in the lawsuit include: Juan David Gomez, Alex Rabin, Amnay Labou, Bryan Anderson, Alex Kaskel, and Alex Mendik.

The Post reached out to Peak Capital Advisors but didn‚Äôt hear back immediately.
item.author: Emily Crane

item.description:
Popular Italian restaurant Fresco by Scotto was robbed of more than $2 million by its brazen bookkeeper ‚Äî who allegedly used the siphoned cash to buy a house, pay her husband‚Äôs internet bills and line her own pockets, The Post has learned.

Lori Jakubowski is facing charges that she embezzled $2.5 million for the Midtown East hotspot co-owned by Channel 5‚Äôs ‚ÄúGood Day New York‚Äù anchor Rosanna Scotto, according to the Manhattan District Attorney‚Äôs Office.

Prosecutors in DA Alvin Bragg‚Äôs office said that Jakubowski ran the grand scheme over a seven-year period, stealing money in any way she could ‚Äî from snatching cash tips to writing herself checks from the eatery‚Äôs bank account.

The embezzled moolah helped fund her lifestyle away from work, including at least $100,000 she used to buy a house in Pennsylvania with her husband, prosecutors said.

‚Äú(She) used the restaurant‚Äôs bank account to pay for her husband‚Äôs Spectrum Internet bill,‚Äù Assistant District Attorney Stephen MacArthur said at Jakubowski first court appearance in the case Wednesday.

Jakubowski was also ‚Äúoverpaying herself by issuing unauthorized pay checks allegedly for vacation time,‚Äù MacArthur said in court.

As part of the scheme to purchase the $164,500 home, Jakubowski allegedly made out 88 separate checks and money orders and cashed them over a four-day period, according to court documents.

Manhattan Criminal Court Judge Althea Drysdale agreed to release Jakubowski on supervision ‚Äî but warned her the decision wasn‚Äôt a ‚Äúget out of court free card.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs much as you have that other abode in Pennsylvania, you must come to court when I tell you to come to court. Do you understand?‚Äù the judge asked, to which Jakubowski responded ‚ÄúI understand.‚Äù

Jakubowski was indicted on grand larceny and falsifying business records charges and faces up to 25 years behind bars, if convicted of the top count.

She pleaded not guilty to all charges.

Her attorney, Michael Fineman, did not comment after the arraignment. She‚Äôs due back in court on Feb. 28, 2026.

Fresco by Scotto, owned by Rosanna and her children Jenn and LJ Ruggiero, recently renewed its lease at 485 Madison Avenue.

The eatery opened in 1993 and bills itself as offering an ‚Äúextension of true Italian hospitality,‚Äù according to its website.

A spokesperson for Fresco by Scotto said it was cooperating with the investigation.
item.author: Kyle Schnitzer

item.description:
Anything is pastable.

When Forma Pasta Factory first opened its doors in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in 2019, they never dreamed they‚Äôd become America‚Äôs top eatery for Italian delivery this year, according to a recent DoorDash report.

In fact, they originally planned to forego delivery service altogether.

So when the third-party app announced America‚Äôs Favorite Delivery Spots of 2025 on Wednesday, based on customer ratings, Forma‚Äôs owner, Amit Rabinovich, was ‚Äúpleasantly surprised.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve only been around for seven years, and almost half that time was under pandemic,‚Äù Rabinovich told The Post, calling the turn of events a ‚Äúfunny thing.‚Äù

With an open-kitchen layout where they make fresh pasta daily, the goal was to have customers try the pasta inside the restaurant to get a full experience, where they could see their food being made and eat it fresh off their warmed ceramic plates.

‚ÄúDelivery was not a thing we wanted to do,‚Äù Rabinovich, 42, admitted. ‚ÄúWe got our arm twisted ‚Äî our first-year anniversary coincided pretty much with the shutdown.‚Äù

The Forma team went into ‚Äúsurvival mode,‚Äù testing dishes over and over to develop the best product they could, even ‚Äî and especially ‚Äî via courier for homebound New Yorkers.

‚ÄúObviously, it‚Äôs never the same, but we were adamant about still trying to give a great experience to the customer,‚Äù Rabinovich said. ‚ÄúWe are very quality-control driven, whether it comes to our in-house customers or delivery.‚Äù

Working with homemade pasta is a delicious but delicate endeavor. At Froma, chefs are careful to prepare orders as close to delivery time as possible ‚Äî and they only deliver within a two- to three-mile radius from each restaurant location to ensure it‚Äôs piping hot and not a bit overcooked on arrival.

‚ÄúWe have a team that works really hard to push consistency and quality,‚Äù Rabinovich said.

But to Rabinovich, nothing means more than the fact that the honor comes from their hungry supporters.

‚ÄúDoorDash is customers,‚Äù he gushed. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nice to know that all the hard work is at least being appreciated by the people.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not a big name or anything like that, so we were really, really happy.‚Äù

Does delivery actually deliver?

Though it‚Äôs technically out of their delivery zone, Forma Pasta Factory did the truly heroic thing by dropping off six hearty handmade pastas straight from their Brooklyn kitchen to The Post‚Äôs Midtown office for the team to conduct a taste test of the restaurant‚Äôs beloved takeout.

The spread ‚Äî which had Post reporters and editors leaping out of their chairs to grab a forkful ‚Äî looked like a carb-lover‚Äôs fever dream: silky fettuccine funghi swimming in rosemary-thyme cream sauce; classic rigatoni vodka adorned with smoked calabrian chili, sun-dried tomatoes and Parmigiano-Reggiano; hearty pappardelle bolognese made with flavorful ground beef ragu and San Marzano tomatoes; zesty mafaldine scampi with lemon-butter shrimp; spaghetti pomodoro that we received with meatballs in tow; and a cozy bowl of pipette ragu with Italian sausage and herb cream.

They even tossed in sides ‚Äî cauliflower, seasonal greens, a gem salad, a kale Caesar ‚Äî plus focaccia and biscotti to finish the job of ruining everyone‚Äôs willpower.

It might‚Äôve all looked and smelled delicious ‚Äî but did these takeout offerings live up to the hype?

Takeout pasta can be hit or miss since it can often arrive at someone‚Äôs doorstep either in a skimpy takeout container or as a soggy mess if it‚Äôs in sauce longer than it should have during the commute.

In between bites, The Post team collectively agreed that all the delivered pastas arrived perfectly al dente, despite some of the noodles clinging to each other in their respective takeout containers ‚Äî something we were able to overlook, considering the 40-minute trek the dishes endured.

The team declared the fettuccine funghi a knockout ‚Äî a rich, creamy dish with a whisper of smoky mushroom magic that left us wondering what fungi sorcery they‚Äôre using.

Another standout was the pappardelle bolognese, which arrived loaded with a rich, beefy rag√π ‚Äî not like a sad Hamburger Helper imitation some spots try to pass off ‚Äî plus bright San Marzano tomatoes. The sauce was creamy, extremely flavorful and genuinely satisfying.

As for the vodka pasta, our editors were beyond impressed: every paccheri noodle had the perfect bite ‚Äî a miracle in the world of takeout, where short pasta often gets cooked into oblivion ‚Äî and each piece was luxuriously coated in rich, pink sauce.

The spaghetti pomodoro with meatballs tasted exactly how a hungry New Yorker would want it to taste: sweet from the tomatoes, savory from the meatballs.

Our assessment: New Yorkers are right. Forma‚Äôs takeout is just as delicious as their dine-in offerings.

And since scoring a table at one of its cramped but cozy Brooklyn locations can be a challenge, those lucky ‚Äî and local ‚Äî enough to snag takeout from the red-sauce joint should count their blessings.
item.author: Brooke Steinberg, Marissa Matozzo

item.description:
Two people were killed, and two others were wounded in a shooting at a Newark, New Jersey recording studio Wednesday night, according to reports.

The sound of the gunfire drowned out the ordinary music bumping out of the recording studio Platinum Sound late Wednesday, according to witnesses who spoke to ABC7.

One man was shot and died at the scene, and another man was shot and later pronounced dead at the hospital, law enforcement sources told the local station.

Two other male victims were wounded by gunfire and taken to the hospital in stable condition, the outlet reported.

The victims‚Äô identities have not yet been released.

Newark police and detectives swarmed the area surrounding the recording studio on Clinton Avenue into late Wednesday night.

No arrests have been confirmed, and it is unclear how many gunmen carried out the shooting, the outlet said.

A preliminary investigation by Newark police found that the shooting was likely a hit on an individual, according to the station.

The Essex County Prosecutor‚Äôs Office and Newark Police did not immediately respond to The Post‚Äôs request for comment.

The shooting remains under investigation.
item.author: Zoe Hussain

item.description:
A New Jersey man who claimed to have tried to save his elderly neighbor by running inside her burning home has been charged with her murder five months later.

William Ahle, 70, was arrested on Wednesday for starting the fatal house fire in Fanwood on July 25, which claimed the life of Virginia Cranwell, Union County Prosecutor William A. Daniel announced.

Ahle is believed to have called 911 to report smoke coming from a second-story bedroom at Cranwell‚Äôs home on Kempshall Terrace.

He told officials he had been walking his dog at 1:30 a.m. when he noticed the fire and rushed into Cranwell‚Äôs open garage in an attempt to rescue her, but was pushed back by the flames, WABC reported.

During his alleged heroics, Ahle suffered serious burns and was taken to the Burn Center at Cooperman Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston.

Firefighters extinguished the blaze in 20 minutes, but found Cranwell unresponsive in her bedroom. She was pronounced dead at the scene.

Officials launched an investigation into the fire and found the cause was an intentional act, Daniel said.

The Union County Medical Examiner‚Äôs Office ruled Cranwell‚Äôs death a homicide, identifying Ahle as the primary suspect.

A SWAT team stormed into Ahle‚Äôs house Wednesday morning and arrested him, witnesses told WABC.

Ahle was charged with first-degree murder, first-degree felony murder, first-degree burglary, and second-degree aggravated arson.¬†

Residents of the quiet neighborhood were surprised to find out Ahle is the suspect in Cranwell‚Äôs death.

‚ÄúThe guy was in the hospital with a lot of bad burns after he tried to rescue her. I really find that hard to believe,‚Äù one neighbor told the outlet.

‚ÄúI can just say that I‚Äôm shocked. He‚Äôs a neighbor, and he seems like a great guy. And he originally helped her. He tried to save her. So it doesn‚Äôt make any sense, I just don‚Äôt understand,‚Äù the neighbor said.

Ahle is being held at the Middlesex County Jail pending his next court appearance, officials said.
item.author: Nicholas McEntyre

item.description:
A Florida man convicted of raping a 27-year-old woman over two decades ago in her Midtown Manhattan apartment finally received his punishment at a sentencing on Wednesday.

Jancys Santiago, 50, was sentenced to 20 years behind bars and five years of post-release supervision for the May 2000 rape that went unsolved for over 25 years, the Manhattan District Attorney‚Äôs Office announced in a statement.

On May 23, 2000, the 27-year-old victim came home and discovered Santiago, masked and hiding in her closet, officials said.

He forced the woman into her bathroom, claiming he was wielding a knife and gun, and threatened to kill her. Santiago then viciously tied her arms and feet with a wire hanger and raped her, according to prosecutors.

A DNA profile created from the evidence in the survivor‚Äôs rape kit was indicted in 2005 by the Manhattan District Attorney‚Äôs Office as ‚ÄúJohn Doe.‚Äù

It wasn‚Äôt until December 2023 that Santiago was identified and charged with the May 2000 rape ‚Äî and a 2001 rape of a 21-year-old woman in the Bronx ‚Äî due to a cutting-edge genetic tracing method.

A three-year $500,000 grant from the US Department of Justice‚Äôs Bureau of Justice Assistance for the Bronx District Attorney‚Äôs Office to solve cold cases was used to fund the review of crime scene evidence that landed the rapist behind bars.

Santiago, who was living in Groveland, Fla., was extradited to New York to face charges after his arrest.

On Sept. 30, he was found guilty of rape in the first degree and burglary in the first degree for the Manhattan case.

In the Bronx case, Santiago allegedly broke into a 21-year-old woman‚Äôs apartment while she was sleeping in December 2001, prosecutors added.

He similarly covered her face, bound her with a wire hanger, and raped her, authorities alleged.

Her rape kit generated a donor profile that matched the donor profile from Santiago‚Äôs Manhattan rape case.

The Bronx rape 2001 rape case remains open, officials said.

‚ÄúAfter 25 years of evading accountability, Jancys Santiago was sentenced to a substantial prison term for raping a woman in her own home,‚Äù District Attorney Alvin Bragg said in a statement.

‚ÄúDogged investigators and my Office‚Äôs prosecutors ensured that this cold case was closed, and Santiago was convicted at trial. I thank the survivor for testifying about this horrific crime after so many years, and for her words at today‚Äôs sentencing,‚Äù Bragg added.
item.author: Zoe Hussain

item.title: ‚Äú‰∫Ü‰∏çËµ∑ÁöÑÈ∫¶ÁëüÂ∞îÂ§´‰∫∫‚ÄùÂ•≥ÊºîÂëòÊ∏©Â¶Æ¬∑Â••Â∞îÈ°ø¬∑Êà¥Áª¥ÊñØÔºà Wenne Alton Davis ÔºâË¢´Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂá∫ÁßüËΩ¶ÊíûÊ≠ªÔºåÊµ∑ÂÖ≥ÂíåËæπÂ¢É‰øùÊä§Â±ÄÂÆòÂëòÂ∏åÊúõÂæàÂø´ÈÄÄ‰ºëÔºöÈÇªÂ±Ö
item.description:
‚ÄúThe Marvelous Mrs. Maisel‚Äù actress who was struck and killed by a taxi while crossing a Midtown street was a Customs and Border Protection officer who had been looking forward to retiring ‚Äî and was cherished for her warm greetings, her devastated neighbors told The Post.

Wendy Davis ‚Äî whose stage name was Wenne Alton Davis ‚Äî worked full-time as a Customs agent at John F. Kennedy International Airport, even powering through the recent government shutdown without pay. She moonlighted as an actress, picking up small roles on the side, including a bit part as a cop in the Emmy-winning Amazon Prime series.

‚ÄúShe was a very bright and kind person,‚Äù her 80-year-old Queens neighbor, Miok Lee, said Wednesday night.

‚ÄúShe was always very active. She did sports, I believe she did rowing. She was very lively. I saw her just a few days ago, and we said hello. Oh my gosh, it‚Äôs so sad, it‚Äôs so shocking, my goodness.‚Äù

Davis was crossing Broadway near the West 53rd Street intersection just before 9 p.m. Monday when a 61-year-old Big Apple taxi driver in a Cadillac hit her while making a left turn, authorities and sources said.

The 60-year-old Queens resident suffered severe head and body trauma and was rushed to Mount Sinai West Hospital, where she succumbed to her injuries, cops said.

‚ÄúShe was the best, she was so nice,‚Äù another Forest Hills neighbor said, adding that despite her long hours at work, she never missed a chance to offer a friendly greeting ‚Äî even on bad days.

‚ÄúShe was always working. I would see her walking out at 4 a.m. or coming back at 2 a.m. She was working towards her retirement. This is a shock,‚Äù the stunned local continued, noting Davis lived alone with her beloved cat Roxie.

‚ÄúThis last weekend she went to go visit her parents and now this happened. It‚Äôs unbelievable.‚Äù

Davis had nine other acting credits listed on her IMDB, including small roles in the 2011 Michael Fassbender drama ‚ÄúShame‚Äù and the 2004 short film ‚ÄúLadies Room.‚Äù

Neighbor Davin Hatsengate said he had no idea she moonlighted as an actress.

‚ÄúShe was super friendly,‚Äù the 51-year-old said.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know she was an actress. I guess she just wanted to be a regular neighbor. It‚Äôs terrible.‚Äù

The JFK Customs Hockey Club also mourned Davis‚Äôs tragic loss on Tuesday.

‚ÄúThis heartbreaking loss is felt deeply across our entire JFK Customs family,‚Äù the Instagram post read.

‚ÄúOur thoughts, prayers, and deepest condolences are with Wendy‚Äôs family and loved ones during this incredibly difficult time. This tragedy has been felt throughout our brotherhood/sisterhood.‚Äù

The driver who struck her remained at the grim scene and cooperated with investigators, police said.

He had not been charged as of Wednesday.
item.author: Jennifer Bain, Anna Young

item.title: Âá∫ÁßüËΩ¶Âè∏Êú∫ÁöÑÂ∞∏‰ΩìË¢´ÂèëÁé∞ÂÄæÂÄíÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∑ûÂåóÈÉ®ÁöÑÊ∞¥Â∫ì‰∏≠‚ÄîÂá∂Êâã‰∏é‰ªñÁöÑÂá∫ÁßüËΩ¶‰∏ÄËµ∑ÈÄÉËµ∞ÔºöË≠¶ÂØü
item.description:
A 66-year-old taxi driver reported missing from Connecticut was killed and dumped in an upstate New York reservoir ‚Äî with a massive police manhunt now underway to find the culprit.

Aurelio Zhunio-Orbez, who was reported missing the Danbury Police Department on Dec. 1, was found by a fisherman Sunday, floating in the Croton Falls Reservoir in Putnam County, the county sheriff said.

Police also issued an alert for Zhunio-Orbez‚Äôs cab, a black Toyota Sienna, which was stolen by the killer.

‚ÄúFollowing a post-mortem examination, the Office of the Putnam County Coroner has ruled the death a homicide,‚Äù the sheriff said in a release. ‚ÄúA comprehensive criminal investigation is underway.‚Äù

Danbury police said on Facebook that Zhunio-Orbez was last seen around 11:30 p.m. on Dec. 1 at the Brewster, New York, Metro-North station while working as a livery driver.

The car has ORBESTAXI.COM on the rear, along with ‚ÄúV89‚Äù marked on the back left side and a white taxi sign mounted on the roof, according to a report by ABC7 Eyewitness News.

The Connecticut department referred any questions about the case to the Putnam County sheriff.

‚ÄúMy uncle was a dedicated father, brother, uncle, and friend,‚Äù the dead man‚Äôs niece, Isabel Alvarado, wrote in a gofundme.com page to raise funds for his family. ‚ÄúHe was deeply loved within his community and in other communities as well. As a local taxi driver, he built strong connections with the people he served, and many came to appreciate his kindness, generosity, and hard work.

‚ÄúSadly, there are individuals in this world who take advantage of those who are most vulnerable, and now our family is facing an irreparable loss,‚Äù she wrote.

The site has a goal of $7,000 and has raised just over $3,000 by Wednesday evening.¬†
item.author: Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.description:
A serial burglar who racked up 17 previous arrests stole dough out of a Brooklyn synagogue¬†and then used the subway tracks for his unsuccessful escape route, police said Wednesday.¬†

Career criminal Arthur Jack, 55, crept into Congregation Shaarei Zion of Bobov and snatched $285 from a locked donation box around 4:45 a.m. Wednesday¬†near 15th Avenue and 48th Street in Borough Park, according to cops.

Jack then fled but was tailed for more than half a mile by eagle-eyed witnesses who were inside the synagogue at the time of the crime, the NYPD said.

The career criminal jumped on elevated train tracks on the 50th Street D line in a desperate¬†attempt for¬†freedom ‚Äî but cops eventually caught up to the unholy thief at the station.

He was charged with burglary, criminal trespassing and criminal possession of stolen property ‚Äî racking up his 18th arrest, according to officials. ¬†

It‚Äôs not his first time stealing from Big Apple temples.¬†

In 2012, the crook broke into a Flatbush synagogue and ran off with a bottle of vodka and scotch, authorities said.

He was also busted that same year for a slew of burglaries in Brooklyn, cops said.

Jack spent 10 years behind bars at Fishkill Correctional Institution in Dutchess County on burglary¬†raps and was released in 2023, prison records show.¬†

He was awaiting arraignment in Brooklyn Criminal Court Wednesday night.¬†
item.author: Joe Marino, Steven Vago

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Âº∫Â§ßÁöÑ1199 SEIUÂ∑•‰ºöÂ∑≤Áªè‰ªéÂ∑ûÈïøHochulÊ∂âÂ´åÊìçÁ∫µÁöÑ$ 110‰∫øÂåªÁñóË°•Âä©ËÆ°ÂàíÊîπÈÄ†‰∏≠ÂèóÁõäÔºöÊù•Ê∫ê
item.description:
ALBANY ‚Äì New York‚Äôs powerful 1199 SEIU union is already cashing in on Gov. Kathy Hochul‚Äôs disastrous and allegedly rigged revamp of the state‚Äôs $11 billion home care Medicaid program, The Post has learned.

The politically influential labor group has started moving to unionize the hundreds of thousands of home health aides employed through the allegedly fraud-ridden taxpayer-funded program, and will likely reap a massive windfall in dues.

Officials from 1199, which supported the overhaul, have been meeting weekly with Public Partnerships LLC, the company that was awarded the contract to manage the massive Consumer Directed Personal Assistance Program as part of Hochul‚Äôs reshuffle.

Hochul‚Äôs administration has for months been dogged by allegations that the bidding process for the roughly $1 billion contract to oversee the CDPAP payroll was rigged in favor of PPL.

‚ÄúEveryone ‚Äî taxpayers, consumers, providers ‚Äî loses if 1199 SEIU unionizes the CDPAP program,‚Äù Ken Girardin, a fellow at the Manhattan Institute, told The Post.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no room for a labor union between consumers and the people they hire and train. This would be nothing more than an excuse to skim cash and feed 1199 SEIU‚Äôs political apparatus,‚Äù Girardin said.¬†

‚ÄúThe White House needs to step in because this would be one of the worst abuses of taxpayer money in the history of the Medicaid program.‚Äù

A rep for 1199 didn‚Äôt deny its efforts to unionize the upwards of 200,000 aides in the program. Sources said 1199 may get enough interested members to hold a formal election to create the union beginning in 2026.

‚ÄúWe have called upon PPL ‚Äì as we did other companies that bid for the single fiscal intermediary contract ‚Äì not to waste valuable public dollars pressuring their employees and instead allow workers to make their own decisions about forming a union through a democratic process,‚Äù 1199 SEIU spokeswoman Rose Ryan wrote in a statement.¬†

‚Äú1199 has always been an important stakeholder in CDPAP and we will continue to work closely with them throughout the transition.‚Äù

The move comes as evidence continues to mount suggesting Hochul‚Äôs administration worked to steer the contract to PPL ‚Äî this time in an email unearthed by the government watchdog group Empire Center for Public Policy.

The communications appear to confirm that officials from Hochul‚Äôs office and the state Department of Health met with reps from PPL on April 4 ‚Äî weeks before Albany lawmakers signed off on giving the company the contract.

The governor pushed for the CDPAP overhaul last year, saying she wanted to slash rampant waste, fraud and abuse in the program, which had ballooned to $11 billion from $3 billion in 2018.

The revamp consolidated hundreds of middlemen firms ‚Äî which acted as ‚Äúfiscal intermediaries‚Äù between Medicaid, which funds the program, and the home health aides employed by it ‚Äî under one company‚Äôs umbrella.

But a letter obtained by The Post shows the company handpicked by Hochul‚Äôs DOH for the effort is preparing to saddle the state with more costs next year.

The Health Plans Association, a group representing the insurance providers who front the payroll money to PPL before getting reimbursed by the state, accused the company of making a ‚Äúsignificant increase‚Äù to its rates with ‚Äúno detailed justification‚Äù with no substantive involvement from DOH, the letter shows.

‚ÄúIf PPL insists on its one-size-fits-all, non-negotiable rate, it will put at risk services to members and will undoubtedly undermine the very financial savings that the State projected,‚Äù the HPA wrote.

A spokesperson for PPL maintained that the rate increase was due to a statutory 55-cent spike in the minimum wage for home care workers going into effect in 2026.

‚ÄúPPL retains nothing from the increase and every added dollar goes directly to worker pay. This adjustment does not violate PPL‚Äôs contract,‚Äù the company‚Äôs rep said.

Regarding the April 4 meeting with Hochul admin staffers, the PPL spokesperson declined to share details of the conversation but said it followed a legal, competitive bidding process for the contract.

A spokesperson for the governor‚Äôs office declined to address PPL‚Äôs rising rates and wouldn‚Äôt provide details on the meeting.

Many state lawmakers have soured on the overhaul they signed off on as part of the state budget last year and have expressed serious concerns about the bid-rigging claims.

‚ÄúAs federal cuts threaten to unravel Medicaid‚Äôs foundation, every public dollar must be protected and directed‚Äîtoward people, not profit,‚Äù state Sen. Robert Jackson (D-Manhattan) said.

Jackson and Hochul‚Äôs estranged Lt. Gov. Antonio Delgado made their fury over the overhaul known at a press conference hosted by the advocacy group New York caring majority at the state capitol Wednesday.

Despite the mess, Hochul continued to argue the overhaul was a victory, telling reporters last week that her budget office projected $1 billion in savings year-to-year, half of which from the state and half from the feds.

‚ÄúIt made sense. It was a war, was a major fight, and those are the kind of issues I‚Äôm willing to take on,‚Äù Hochul said.

Some fiscal experts still question whether the state will actually save money overall from the transition to one company, given that around 80,000 consumers left CDPAP for other home care programs.

‚ÄúThis transition caused many tens of thousands of consumers to switch to agency care which is a more expensive form of care,‚Äù Michael Kinnucan, Health Policy Director at the Fiscal Policy Institute, told The Post.

‚ÄúSome of the savings is illusory.‚Äù
item.author: Vaughn Golden

item.description:
A Long Island bank robber hit two Flagstar locations just 5 miles apart ‚Äî in a 48-hour spree where he used a stickup note to scare tellers into handing over cash, cops said.

The thief ‚Äî described as a bald man sporting a beard and a dark-colored jacket ‚Äî first struck on Monday and walked out with an undisclosed amount of cash and hopped into a car outside, cops said.

Just two days later, a man matching the same exact description walked into another Flagstar in North Babylon and pulled the same stunt ‚Äî handing the teller another robbery note before walking out with the stolen money and escaping on foot, cops said.¬†

Detectives told The Post they believe the thief in both robberies are the same person and the investigation is ongoing.¬†

Officials have not released any further information on the alleged thief or regarding the amount of money stolen in the string of robberies.

Representatives from Flagstar Bank did not respond to The Post‚Äôs request for comment.
item.author: Brandon Cruz

item.title: Êó∂‰ª£ÂπøÂú∫ÁöÑÊúÄÂêé‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÊΩúÊ∞¥ÈÖíÂêßÂú®ÁªèÂéÜ‰∫Ü50Âπ¥ÁöÑÂïÜ‰∏öÁîüÊ∂ØÂêéÁªàË∫´Â•ãÊñóÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Durst OrganizationÂ∏åÊúõÈ©±ÈÄê
item.description:
He‚Äôs not going to take a dive.

The owner of Jimmy‚Äôs Corner ‚Äî Times Square‚Äôs last remaining dive bar ‚Äî is fighting to keep his father‚Äôs boxing-themed watering hole alive against a highly personal attack from its bigwig landlord.

Adam Lee Glenn, 44, sued the Durst Organization last week to prevent the real estate giant from evicting the West 44rd Street bar after more than 50 years in business.

The suit contends Durst officials looking to sell the building want to declare the lease void because the bar‚Äôs namesake Jimmy Glenn died in 2020 ‚Äî arguably a betrayal of the close friendship he shared with the company‚Äôs former Seymour Durst.

‚ÄúI sort of always knew that one day ‚Äî and I hoped it was far away ‚Äî like progress is going to come,‚Äù Adam Glenn said. ‚ÄúBut I hoped that when it did, it would come in the right way and that they would sort of have the grace and the decency to do this in a way that works for all of us.

‚ÄúI feel like they‚Äôve taken a position that they don‚Äôt need to do that. And so, you know, I took the position that if you‚Äôre not going to do the decent thing, then I‚Äôm going to fight you.‚Äù

The hole-in-the-wall was opened in the early 1970s by Jimmy Glenn, a Hall of Fame boxing trainer who stuffed its narrow walls with memorabilia from the sweet science.

He also fought against the ‚ÄúBad Old Days‚Äù seediness of Times Square, then replete with sex shops, prostitutes and gangsters.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm proud that I still get people who come, like, who used to live in the building next door,‚Äù Adam Glenn said.

‚ÄúAnd they said, ‚ÄòI lived in Times Square in the 80s and the only reason I felt safe was because I knew Jimmy was here. The only reason this block felt okay was because your family watched out for us.'‚Äù

As Times Square went from tawdry to touristy over the decades, Jimmy‚Äôs Corner remained an oasis for locals and travelers alike who are thirsty for $3 beer and a taste of a bygone era.

‚ÄúJimmy‚Äôs bar is one of the last legs that represent New York,‚Äù said Clarence Sessoms III, 36, a bar regular from the Bronx.

‚ÄúYou take Jimmy‚Äôs out of New York, you take the foundation from New York.‚Äù

Dan Dion, 55, has been patronizing the bar for 25 years during his frequent visits to the city from Nashville, Tennessee.

‚ÄúEverybody‚Äôs welcome here, everybody feels comfortable here and in the world of Times Square that has changed so much in 25 years, this place hasn‚Äôt changed at all,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúIt should have landmark status as far as I‚Äôm even concerned.‚Äù

Glenn rented from Durst until the real estate magnate‚Äôs death in 1995, when his son Douglas Durst ‚Äî another friend ‚Äî took over, according to the lawsuit.

Douglas Durst‚Äôs bizarre, burping older brother Robert Durst was infamously profiled in the 2015 HBO documentary ‚ÄúThe Jinx,‚Äù which featured an apparent accidental confession to at least one murder. He was sidelined from his family‚Äôs business.

‚ÄúJames Glenn and both Seymour and Douglas Durst spoke, at various times, of their desire that their respective businesses be eventually taken over and operated by their children,‚Äù the suit states.

But the lawsuit contends the landlords took advantage of an elderly Glenn and his friendship with the Dursts as they hashed out a 2019 lease with terms they‚Äôre now using to kickstart an eviction.

Jimmy Glenn died from COVID-19 in 2020 and his son Adam stepped in as owner.

In 2023, Adam Glenn ran into trouble with the Durst landlords when they tried to terminate the lease because many bar patrons, who happened to be black men, went outside to smoke ‚Äî a move the lawsuit alleges was racist.

The kerfuffle passed until this year, when Durst landlords told Glenn they would terminate the lease ‚Äî arguing it was void after his death and long before its stated end in 2029, according to the lawsuit.

Jimmy Glenn would never have signed a lease modification that would effectively end his family legacy, the lawsuit contends.

A Durst Organization spokesperson said the company tried to keep the bar‚Äôs doors open for decades because of the two families‚Äô relationship.

When the company ultimately decided to sell the building, it went ‚Äúabove and beyond‚Äù the lease obligations out of respect of Jimmy Glenn, the spokesperson contended.

‚ÄúWe told Adam Glenn over a year ago he would have to vacate the building, we offered him $250,000 even though we were not required to do so, and allowed the bar to remain open longer,‚Äù the spokesperson said. ‚ÄúThese efforts have not been met with good faith. We have done our best to be good neighbors, and we regret it has come to this. This is truly the story of no good deed goes unpunished.‚Äù

Adam Glenn said he expected he‚Äôd have to move the bar someday, although he‚Äôd hope to do so ‚Äúthe right way.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere will always be a Jimmy‚Äôs Corner in New York and I will find a forever home,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut in the meantime, I‚Äôm not going to stop fighting to be here.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre still a slice of old New York. People come in and they feel a little touch of, ‚ÄòOh, this is what New York used to be.‚Äô And I like giving people a real New York experience.‚Äù
item.author: Estrella McDaniel, Matt Troutman

item.title: ËÅîÈÇ¶Ë∞ÉÊü•Â±ÄÊé®Âá∫È¶ñ‰∏™ÊâìÂáª‚ÄúÊºîÂèò‚ÄùË∑®ÂõΩÊúâÁªÑÁªáÁäØÁΩ™ÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶ÁâπÂà´Â∑•‰ΩúÁªÑ
item.description:
Federal authorities launched a first-of-its-kind task force in New York that law enforcement leaders vowed Wednesday would tackle ‚Äúevolving threats presented by transnational organized crime.‚Äù

US Attorney prosecutors, the FBI, Homeland Security, the IRS and the NYPD unveiled the new Homeland Security Task Force (HSTF) New York that takes aim at notorious cartels and foreign gangs that set their sets on the Big Apple.

The task force would better streamline intelligence obtained across agencies at every level of government, officials said in Lower Manhattan during a press conference.

‚ÄúThis task force is the first of its kind, using a whole government approach through a unified framework, the HSTF serves as a model for protecting the homeland from evolving threats presented by transnational organized crime,‚Äù said Ricky Patel, who is the Homeland Security Investigations New York special agent in charge.

US Attorney for the Southern District of New York Jay Clayton said while crime is down, it‚Äôs still stubbornly too high in vulnerable neighborhoods.

‚ÄúNew Yorkers want public safety. They want our parks, schools, subways and streets to be both safe places and places that feel safe for our families, our children and our visitors,‚Äù he said at the Wednesday press conference.

He cited the recent raid on Washington Square Park that led to the arrest of nearly 20 alleged drug dealers as law enforcement collaboration.

The task force will heavily focus on Foreign Terrorist Organizations with FBI New York Assistant Director in Charge Christopher Raia stating the feds are seeking two high-ranking members of the dangerous cartel Jalisco New Generation Cartel, which received the terror designation earlier this year.

While the official rollout was this week, Patel noted, ‚ÄúThis historic, unified collaboration of sharing of resources has already been in motion behind the scenes.‚Äù
item.author: Desheania Andrews, David Propper

item.description:
A 45-year-old man was¬†stabbed in the back during a Wednesday morning rush-hour clash inside the buzzing Union Square subway station,¬†cops said.¬†

The victim was making his way toward the¬†L train platform at the 14th Street-Union Square hub around 10 a.m. when the¬†menace knifed him in the back during a dispute, authorities said.

He was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where he was listed in stable condition, police said.¬†

The male attacker fled the scene and was still on the loose Wednesday evening.

It was not immediately clear whether the two men knew each other, or what sparked the violent dust-up.¬†

In an unrelated burst of violence a day earlier, a 15-year-old boy was stabbed repeatedly and left seriously hurt after a fight broke out on board a Bronx bus, cops and sources said.

The teen was knifed multiple times during a clash with two apparent strangers at Bartow and Wickham avenues in Baychester around 2:40 p.m., police and sources said.

It was unclear whether the boy was stabbed on board the bus or if he was attacked after getting off.¬†

He was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where he was listed in critical but stable condition,¬†police said.¬†

No arrests had been made by Wednesday.
item.author: Joe Marino, Amanda Woods

item.title: ÈïøÂ≤õDAÊé®Âä®Âº•Ë°•ÊØíÂìÅÈ©æÈ©∂Ê≥ïÂæã‰∏≠ÁöÑËá¥ÂëΩÊºèÊ¥ûÔºö ‚ÄúËøôÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÖ®Â∑ûËåÉÂõ¥ÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢ò‚Äù
item.description:
New York metro area prosecutors and pols huddled in Times Square on Wednesday in a push to beef up the Empire State‚Äôs drugged driving statute ‚Äî bashing loopholes in the current law.

Suffolk County District Attorney Ray Tierney hosted the first-ever Drugged Driving Symposium as officials called for state lawmakers to sign off on a bill languishing in committee that would add to the list of drugs that qualify for a DUI charge under state law.

‚ÄúNew York State is one of only four states that permits dangerously impaired people to drive illegally on New York State roadways because the substance they are using doesn‚Äôt happen to be on a public health law list,‚Äù Tierney said at the event at Touro College.

‚ÄúThis loophole allows drivers who are impaired by such substances as propofol, nitrous oxide, xylazine or other emerging synthetic drugs to operate vehicles and threaten the lives of everyday citizens with impunity ‚Äî no matter how impaired they may be on those substances,‚Äù he added.

The state bill would amend Vehicle and Traffic Law to add similar drugs to the list that already includes alcohol, opioids and several powerful prescription drugs ‚Äî but omits others that can have the same effects.

Among those affected by the legal loophole was the family of Stephen McDermott, a 31-year-old who was struck and killed in 2019 by a drugged-up driver ‚Äî who got off because he didn‚Äôt qualify for a DUI rap.

‚ÄúI feel that the system and the state failed us,‚Äù his brother, Michael, said Wednesday. ‚ÄúThe individual had been arrested multiple times prior for drug use and driving while being drugged and nothing was done about it because the substances that he was on weren‚Äôt on the list.‚Äù

Hempstead resident Jawana Richardsoni said her husband, Sherman, was killed by a drugged driver on Dec. 5, 2014 while under the influence, who fled the scene.

She said that driver was ultimately arrested after torching the car ‚Äî an all-too-rare outcome in the cases.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm one of the few who got justice,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy case was an anomaly, because I got justice.‚Äù

But far too many don‚Äôt, organizers said.

‚ÄúThis is not a Long Island issue,‚Äù Manhattan DA Alvin Bragg, a symposium participant, told The Post. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not an upstate issue. It‚Äôs not a city issue. This is a statewide issue.‚Äù

The prosecutor cited a case of a pedestrian killed by a drugged driver in Times Square.

‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôs a drug that is on the list or not on the list, if it does what it did to that driver and it results in the way it did that day, the law should speak to that,‚Äù he said.

Among those on hand were state Assemblyman Steve Stern and state Sen. Chris Ryan.
item.author: Brandon Cruz, Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇDSAÂØπZohran MamdaniÊÑüÂà∞ÈúáÊÉäÔºå‰ºØÂ∞º¬∑Ê°ëÂæ∑ÊñØÔºà Bernie Sanders ÔºâÂú®NY-10ÊØîËµõ‰∏≠ÊîØÊåÅÂ∏ÉÊãâÂæ∑¬∑ÂÖ∞Âæ∑Ôºà Brad Lander ÔºâË∂ÖË∂äÊûÅÂ∑¶ÁøºÊîøÂÖö
item.description:
They are seeing red!

The Big Apple‚Äôs commune of radical socialists freaked out after their de facto leader Zohran Mamdani backed outgoing City Comptroller Brad Lander‚Äôs congressional bid over one of their own far-left comrades.

Lander formally announced his campaign Wednesday morning to primary Rep. Dan Goldman for New York‚Äôs 10th Congressional District ‚Äî a House seat that had also been eyed by lefty City Council member Alexa Avil√©s.

Both Mamdani, the incoming mayor, and Avil√©s are members of the Democratic Socialists of America.

‚ÄúCrazy maneuvering by Zohran and a complete failure for DSA,‚Äù one of the group‚Äôs members opined on social media.

‚ÄúSo basically Zohran, a DSA member, is gonna be endorsing Brad Lander, who is not a DSA member, over Alexa Aviles, a DSA member, in NY-10,‚Äù another wrote.

David-Desyr√©e, who sits on the NYC-DSA Citywide Leadership Committee, was also dismayed by Mamdani‚Äôs latest move to back Lander.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so beyond disappointed in zohran for backing lander and sidestepping the organization that got him elected,‚Äù Desyr√©e wrote on X.

One DSA member didn‚Äôt mince words, writing, ‚ÄúAlso f‚Äìk Brad Lander.‚Äù

Avil√©s was rumored to be eyeing a Democratic primary challenge against two-term congressman Goldman for the Manhattan seat, but had not formally declared.

She responded to Lander‚Äôs campaign announcement ‚Äî which also came with the backing of fellow socialist Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders ‚Äî by bowing out.

‚ÄúIn recent weeks, I have received an outpouring of support from community members encouraging me to run for congress,‚Äù she wrote in a statement. ‚ÄúHowever, after conversations with family and movement, I have decided that there is far too much to be done at home in Brooklyn and at City Hall.

‚ÄúThank you to my comrade in the NYC-DSA,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThe fight for a dignified city has only just begun.‚Äù

Lander had angled for a spot in the Mamdani administration after the two polls cross-endorsed each other in the final days of the Democratic mayoral primary.

But after a falling out with the mayor-elect, according to sources, Lander set his sights on the congressional seat ‚Äî with the seeming consolation prize from Mamdani being clearing the field of a challenge from the far-left.

The endorsement, though, could end up dogging Mamdani as he tries to hold together an unstable alliance of moderate, progressive and socialist Democrats.

The lefty Queens assemblyman also went to bat against fellow DSA member Councilman Chi Oss√©, who ended up dropping his short-lived bid to primary House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries for his Brooklyn seat.
item.author: Craig McCarthy

item.title: ÊØîÂ∞î¬∑Âæ∑Â∏ÉÊãâË•øÂ••Ôºà Bill de Blasio ÔºâÁöÑÂâç‰ªªÊ¨∫È™óÂâçÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂ∏ÇÈïø‚ÄìÂ£∞Áß∞‰ªñÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÂ≠©Â≠êÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÁ¶ªÂºÄÂ•πÂâçÂæÄ‚Äú‰πèÂë≥‚ÄùÁöÑÂçóÂõæÊ£ÆÂ∏ÇÂ∏ÇÈïøÔºö ‚ÄúÂÆ≥ÊÄï‰∫≤ÂØÜÂÖ≥Á≥ª‚Äù
item.description:
New York politico Nomiki Konst ripped her ex-beau, Bill de Blasio, for his ‚Äúfear of intimacy‚Äù ‚Äî and denounced his new lover as ‚Äúvapid‚Äù in a scathing podcast confession.¬†

Konst, 41, candidly dished about her ill-fated love affair with the 64-year-old lefty former mayor ‚Äî and even made the shocking revelation that he was ‚Äúopen‚Äù to having kids with her.¬†

‚ÄúHe was open. Not only open, but he was like asking me lots of questions about having children,‚Äù she told host Toure on the YouTube show ‚ÄúWhy Did They Break Up?‚Äù

‚ÄúOn a flight to California, we talked the entire time about the process and what it would be like,‚Äù she added of de Blasio, who has two adult children he shares with former New York First Lady Chirlane McCray, his wife of over 30 years, whom he separated from in 2023, but has not divorced.

The bombshell statement contradicted previous reporting ‚Äî in which rumors about the two planning for kids were shot down.

‚ÄúHe wanted to have a child with you?‚Äù Toure asked, clarifying.¬†

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù said Konst.¬†

Konst told Toure that the pair‚Äôs 10-month-long whirlwind romance was undermined by de Blasio‚Äôs affinity for chaos.¬†

‚ÄúIt became clear when things were good, suddenly something had to go bad,‚Äù she explained.¬†

‚ÄúI think there might even be a fear of intimacy and being hurt. He did express that one time, like ‚ÄòI‚Äôm scared you‚Äôre going to hurt me.‚Äô‚Äù¬†

But de Blasio was the one who scorned Konst when he invited the Mayor of South Tucson, Roxanna Valenzuela, to lunch in September. Immediately after, the two went up to his apartment.¬†

‚ÄúSalad with a side of F‚Äì!‚Äù Konst joked.¬†

After the initial affair, Konst said she forgave de Blasio and tried to repair their relationship, but he remained in contact with Valenzuela against her wishes.¬†

‚ÄúI miss her,‚Äù the former mayor explained when Konst asked him why he wouldn‚Äôt cut off contact.

Konst said she even appealed to Valenzuela ‚Äî begging her to end the communication ‚Äî but she wouldn‚Äôt relent.¬†

‚ÄúShe was all over the place and kind of whiny and self-indulgent,‚Äù Konst recalled.

A heartbroken Konst confronted de Blasio a final time ahead of SOMOS ‚Äî a political conference in Puerto Rico ‚Äî after finding out he had cancelled his trip to the Island retreat so that Valenzuela could visit him in the Big Apple.

‚ÄúAfter all of this, you‚Äôre talking to this person who you know is not your soulmate, who you‚Äôre no you‚Äôre not going to be with, is vapid, she‚Äôs an unserious person,‚Äù Konst railed.¬†

De Blasio told Page Six on Wednesday that he and Valenzuela are going strong.

‚ÄúI fell in love with someone else and I should have told her sooner. I‚Äôm now in a wonderful relationship with Roxanna Valenzuela that we will continue to nurture and keep private,‚Äù he said.
item.author: Hannah Fierick

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÊ∞ë‰∏ªÂÖöÈÄöËøáÊ≥ïÊ°àÁõ¥Êé•ËÆøÈóÆÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë≠¶ÂØüÂ±ÄÁöÑË∫´‰ΩìÊëÑÂÉèÂ§¥‚ÄîË≠¶ÂØüÂ∞ÜRIPËßÜ‰∏∫‚Äú‰∏çÂøÖË¶ÅÁöÑ‚ÄùÊùÉÂäõÊî´Âèñ
item.description:
The City Council plans to ram through a controversial bill giving the NYPD‚Äôs civilian watchdog direct access to body-worn camera footage ‚Äî¬†despite cops ripping it as an ‚Äúunnecessary‚Äù power grab, The Post has learned.

Outgoing Council Speaker Adrienne Adams will be putting the¬†first-of-its-kind law up for a vote by the full 51-member body next week, while privately boasting to members that it will be part of her ‚Äúlegacy,‚Äù insiders said.

The bill ‚Äî introduced by Adams and co-sponsored by a slate of leftie lawmakers, including Democratic Socialists of America council members Tiffany Caban and Shahana Hanif ‚Äî would give the Civilian Complaint Review Board real-time access to the NYPD servers storing police videos.

The police department‚Äôs largest union railed that the law would continue to force cops off the job by putting officers in the crosshairs of a CCRB emboldened by the new expanded powers.

‚ÄúCouncil members need to understand the message they‚Äôre sending to the cops in their neighborhood,‚Äù Police Benevolent Association President Patrick Hendry said Wednesday.

‚ÄúThe unfairness at CCRB is already a major factor driving police officers away from this job,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBy pushing this unnecessary and legally unfeasible bill to grant CCRB even more power, the Council is actually pushing more dedicated, talented cops out the door.‚Äù

The PBA and the council members opposed to the bill argue it could actually violate state law, citing the Clean Slate Act, which bars authorities from handing over troves of criminal case evidence after a certain period of time or if the charges were dismissed.

‚ÄúThis dangerous CCRB bill would force the NYPD to hand over sealed body-cam footage in clear violation of state law, blowing up privacy protections and due process,‚Äù railed moderate Democratic Councilman Bob Holden (Queens-District 30).

‚ÄúInstead of backing our cops, the Council is pandering to an anti-police board and putting public safety at risk,‚Äù said Holden, who is term-limited and will leave office at the end of the year.

Investigators at the independent oversight agency currently have to request footage from the police department, and the NYPD reviews the video before handing it over.

The CCRB has long griped that the NYPD has dragged its feet on a number of these requests, particularly when the agency was probing complaints against cops during the George Floyd protests in 2020.

Supporters of the bill argue it will boost police transparency and speed up investigation times for the CCRB, which can bring disciplinary¬†cases against cops accused of wrongdoing.

Roughly a dozen council members, including the six Republicans, are opposed to the measure, per The Post‚Äôs count.

But it is still expected to pass when members vote on it Dec. 18, sources said.

Mayor Eric Adams, no relation to the council speaker, didn‚Äôt say whether he would try to veto the bill should it pass before he leaves office at the end of the year.

Even if it was nixed by the mayor, the incoming council next year could still move to override the veto.

Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani, who takes office Jan. 1, 2026, hasn‚Äôt said whether he backs the bill, but has previously argued for expanded powers for the CCRB.

The city‚Äôs Office of Management and Budget said the measure would come with a $10 million price tag for the software and hardware necessary to set the watchdog agency up with real time access to the footage.

The cost could balloon even higher, with OMB expecting a new unit will be needed to manage the data being collected. The council, however, wrote in a fiscal impact summary that it believes the NYPD‚Äôs existing unit could handle such duties.

A council spokesperson said that ‚Äúall bills will comply with state law‚Äù and that there would be a two-year runway to create the software systems.
item.author: Craig McCarthy

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶‰∏ªË¶ÅÂéÜÂè≤ÈõÜÂõ¢ÂÆ£Â∏ÉÂ§ßËßÑÊ®°Êâ©Âº†ÔºåÊ≠£Â•ΩËµ∂‰∏äÁæéÂõΩ250Â≤ÅÁîüÊó•
item.description:
It‚Äôs about time.

The New York Historical announced Tuesday that its long-awaited expansion dedicated to US history will open this summer ‚Äî and just in time for the US‚Äôs blockbuster 250th birthday.

The revolutionary Tang Wing for American Democracy will house a sprawling art gallery, a state-of-the-art conservation lab, a rooftop garden, massive classrooms and the first-ever American LGBTQ+ Museum.

‚ÄúThis wing shall rise as a self-evident embodiment of the American revolution from our humble beginnings as the world‚Äôs first modern democracy to the world‚Äôs longest continuous democracy,‚Äù said archeologist Agnes Hsu-Tang, the chair of the board of trustees whose family‚Äôs massive donation made the new wing possible.

The New York Historical, which dropped ‚ÄúSociety‚Äù from its name last year, offered a sneak peek into the brand new 71,000-square-foot space on Tuesday ‚Äî six months ahead of its June 18 opening day.

The Tang Wing is still very much under construction, with just the bare bones of the massive rooms and classroom spaces taking shape ‚Äî eagerly awaiting paintings to adorn its walls and visitors to flood its space.

The expansion is decades in the making, with numerous proposals, including one that saw condominiums stacked on top of the landmarked museum, failing to break beyond the discussion phase.

The Tang Wing is being constructed behind the original building and does not exceed the museum‚Äôs original height.

It cost roughly $360 million to bring to life, thanks in part to a $125 million donation by Hsu-Tang and her husband, Oscar Tang, whose philanthropy is also responsible for the Tang Center for Early China at¬†Columbia University, the Hsu-Tang Library for Classical Chinese Literature at¬†Oxford University and more.

When completed, the Tang Wing will house a series of exhibitions dedicated to America‚Äôs 250th anniversary ‚Äî which will be celebrated in the Big Apple with a massive week-long blustbuster party.

The brand new Klingenstein Family Gallery will host a ‚ÄúDemocracy Matters‚Äù showcase involving key objects from the museum‚Äôs history that show how democracy has stretched and shifted throughout the centuries, while a ‚ÄúRevolutionary Women‚Äù series will explore the trailblazing females whose contributions to the war effort have been little recognized.

Crucially, the opening will allow The New York Historical to expand the number of students it serves through its four-day-long intensive class each year tenfold, from 3,000 to 30,000 annually.

‚ÄúThis transformative new wing embodies The Historical‚Äôs mission of illuminating the complexities of the American story and inspiring engagement with the ideas and principles that define it,‚Äù said Dr. Louise Mirrer.

‚ÄúAs we approach the nation‚Äôs 250th anniversary, the Tang Wing will serve as both a beacon for civic learning and a space for reflection on the values that continue to shape our democracy.
item.author: Katherine Donlevy

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÁâπÈÅ£ÈÉ®Èòü‰∏∫2026Âπ¥‰∏ñÁïåÊùØÔºàÁæéÂõΩÁ¨¨250Â±ä‰∏ñÁïåÊùØÔºâÁöÑÂ§ßÈáèËßÇ‰ºóÂÅöÂ•Ω‰∫ÜÂáÜÂ§áÔºö ‚ÄúÁõ∏ÂΩì‰∫é9‰∏™Ë∂ÖÁ∫ßÁ¢óÁöÑÂèëÁîü‚Äù
item.description:
It‚Äôs gonna be a hot summer in the Big Apple ‚Äî and the city is ready to keep things cool.

An unprecedented multi-agency task force is prepped to handle a tsunami of tourists expected to descend on the New York metro area for a slew of high-profile events, from World Cup matches across the river in Jersey to Fourth of July and Price Day celebrations.

‚ÄúWe have the equivalent of nine Super Bowls happening in New York City,‚Äù Emergency Management Commissioner Zach Iscol told The Post Wednesday. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre expecting about 3-billion-plus people to watch the World Cup next summer. We‚Äôve got nine games [near] the city.

‚ÄúBut on top of that we have the 250th birthday of America,‚Äù Iscol said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to have fireworks on both rivers. We have ‚ÄòSail 250,‚Äô which is going to be like Fleet Week on steroids, plus we have all the parades and all the other stuff we have in the city that we have to deal with.‚Äù

The NYPD and regional agencies have mastered security at massive events, including New Year‚Äôs Eve in Times Square, the New York City Marathon and even the Super Bowl at MetLife in 2014.

But the crowds are expected to be something else next year.

About 200 representatives from every local, state and federal law enforcement agency huddled at the city‚Äôs Emergency Operations Center in Brooklyn Heights to plan the response, officials said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre having, you know, an unprecedented meeting and operations system for an unprecedented event,‚Äù said Alex Lazary, CEO of the NY/NJ FIFA World Cup Host Committee, which will monitor eight games at MetLife Stadium at the New Jersey Meadowlands from June 11 to July 19.

The cup, the most-watched sporting event in the world, will spill over into the Big Apple with patrons packing bars in the five boroughs for watch parties ‚Äî including a massive gathering scheduled for Rockefeller Center, smack in the middle of Midtown.

Starting with the National Puerto Rican Day Parade and NYC Pride March in June, the crowds are expected to grow in July, with annual Fleet Week and Independence Day, given that it will mark the 250th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence.

That will include ‚ÄúSail 4th‚Äù over the July 4th holiday, which will bring an armada of tall ships into New York Harbor, including the ARM Cuauht√©moc, the Mexican training ship that smashed into the Brooklyn Bridge in May, which will be making it‚Äôs first return voyage to Manhattan.

Even the US Navy is on board for the advance prep work.

‚ÄúThe biggest challenges in coordinating, planning and executing ‚ÄòInternational Naval Review 250‚Äô are basically the number of different elements that the operation encompasses,‚Äù said US Navy Rear Admiral Gavin Duff. ‚ÄúOne is just the sheer size and magnitude, bringing in 95 different ships from both the US and international allies.

‚ÄúAn average Fleet week numbers about five to seven ships,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre in the 18 to 20 times of what is normal.‚Äù

Col. David Sierotowicz ‚Äî Homeland Security Branch commander of the New Jersey State Police, said the biggest challenge for law enforcement prep is getting all partners in various agencies together.

‚ÄúWe want to make sure that they all have the information they need in real time, and everyone is coming to the table as one unit for public safety,‚Äù Sierotowicz said.
item.author: Joe Marino, Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈïø‰∫öÂΩìÊñØË≠¶ÂëäZohran Mamdani ÔºåÊ†ºÈõ∑Ë•øÂ§ßÂé¶ÈóπÈ¨ºÔºö ‚ÄúÂ∞èÂøÉÈ¨ºÈ≠Ç‚Äù
item.description:
Zoh‚Äôs going to get ghosted.

Outgoing woo-woo-loving Mayor Eric Adams spookily warned successor Zohran Mamdani that his soon-to-be new home of Gracie Mansion is haunted.

‚ÄúBeware of the ghost,‚Äù Adams joked during a Tuesday visit to Washington, DC, a Fox Business reporter posted on X.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a friendly ghost, as long as you‚Äôre doing right by the city,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt become right by the city, he turns into a poltergeist.‚Äù

Adams has repeatedly proclaimed that the 226-year-old mayoral residence is also real-life Haunted Mansion ‚Äî but his latest campfire tale also let him indulge in his growing habit of giving Mamdani boos by shading the socialist‚Äôs plans.

Representatives for Mamdani, who announced this week he‚Äôll be moving into Gracie Mansion after he takes office next month, didn‚Äôt respond to Adams‚Äô spectral jibe.

The one-sided ghost adventure came a week after Adams and Mamdani met face-to-face to discuss the ongoing mayoral transition.

The sitdown foreshadowed the end of Adams‚Äô four-year tenure as the Big Apple‚Äôs mayor ‚Äî and time communing with Gracie Mansion‚Äôs restless spirits.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care what anyone says, there are ghosts in there, man,‚Äù Hizzoner¬†told¬†Yankees announcers Michael Kay and Cameron Maybin in 2022, a few months after he moved into the Upper East Side abode.

Adams didn‚Äôt back down on his ghostly beliefs a year later, insisting it‚Äôd be a grave error to ignore the mansion‚Äôs history and ‚Äúenergy.‚Äù

The house, located in Carl Schurz Park in Yorkville, has seen at least two deaths.

Elizabeth Wolcott Gracie, the daughter-in-law of the shipping merchant who built the mansion, succumbed to apoplexy in 1819.

And Susan Wagner ‚Äî the wife of former Mayor Robert Wagner ‚Äî died in the mansion during 1964 after a battle with lung cancer.

‚ÄúYou hear squeaks ‚Ä¶ You hear a door close,‚Äù Adams told CBS New York in 2023. ‚ÄúYou hear, there are different sounds you hear inside the building as I walk around at night, you can hear them.‚Äù

The spooky atmosphere of creaking doors and phantom sounds at Gracie Mansion was also attested by former first lady Chirlane McCray, who shared her experiences during a 2017 Halloween interview.

But McCray‚Äôs husband ‚Äî and post-mayoral ladies man Bill de Blasio ‚Äî didn‚Äôt channel the same astral vibe.

Safe to say, any mayor-to-mayor chats with Fiorello LaGuardia‚Äôs ghost only happened in ‚ÄúGhostbusters II.‚Äù

‚ÄúDuring my eight years at Gracie Mansion, I absolutely positively never heard or saw any ghosts,‚Äù de Blasio told The Post Wednesday.
item.author: Craig McCarthy, Matt Troutman

item.title: Êû™ÂáªJets CBÁöÑÊû™ÊâãKris BoydÊòØ‰∏ÄÂêçËØ¥Âî±Ê≠åÊâãÔºå‰ªñÂú®È¢ÑË®ÄÊÄßÈü≥‰πêËßÜÈ¢ë‰∏≠ÂêπÂòò‚ÄúÊàëÊúâÂáÜÁ°ÆÁöÑÁõÆÊ†á‚Äù
item.description:
The accused¬†gunman who allegedly shot Jets cornerback Kris Boyd is a small-time drill rapper who boasted ‚ÄúI have accurate aim‚Äù in a disturbing, prophecy-filled music video, The Post has learned.
Frederick Green, 20 ‚Äî aka rapper Tbo Zay ‚Äî bragged about guns, glorified violence and even mentioned the pricey vehicle he used to flee the crime scene in a video posted to¬†YouTube three months ago.

‚ÄúI get wavy‚Ä¶I go in the Beemer and I got accurate aim,‚Äù he rapped in his song ‚ÄúMission,‚Äù an apparent reference to a BMW, the same brand car cops connected to him after the Nov. 16 attack.

‚ÄúMultiple scenes where my Glock got wavy,‚Äù he added.

‚ÄúI also shot like I‚Äôm Brady‚Ä¶Throw shots and I‚Äôm waving a pistol.‚Äù

The drill rapper was¬†busted Monday¬†for allegedly blasting Boyd, 29, in the stomach outside the popular Midtown Asian-fusion restaurant Sei-Less on West 38th Street around 2 a.m. on Nov. 16, cops said.

Boyd was out with Gang Green linebacker Jamien Sherwood, wide receiver Irvin Charles and a pal from Texas when a group mocked their flashy outfits outside the hotspot, police said.

The football players headed inside the eatery for about 10 minutes before walking back outside ‚Äî where the group resumed making disparaging comments about¬†their clothes and hurling insults, according to authorities.

Moments later, Green allegedly opened fire, striking Boyd in the gut and then bolting from the scene in a white BMW.

The accused shooter then chopped off his long hair, ditched his phone and hid out in Buffalo at a gal pal‚Äôs apartment in a desperate attempt to throw police off his tail, Assistant District Attorney Sarah Csanadi revealed at his Tuesday night arraignment.

When cops cornered him inside the apartment, he even tried to jump out a window, she said.

Police found him after tracking down a gray Mercedes he drives that is registered to his girlfriend, according to law enforcement sources.

Green was charged with attempted murder, assault and criminal possession of a weapon. He was held without bail Tuesday night.

The shooting left Boyd in critical but stable condition, with a bullet fragment ending up in his lung.
Boyd may require additional surgery and continues to suffer from complications from the wounds, Csanadi said.

The suspect has a rap sheet including four prior arrests ‚Äî most of them sealed ‚Äî including busts earlier this year for unlawful possession of person‚Äôs ID and criminal possession of a controlled substance, sources said.

In the music video, Green dons a black face mask, rides a Citi Bike through the Big Apple Streets with a group of pals and throws up apparent gang signs.

‚ÄúIn real life, n‚Äìs don‚Äôt be a threat,‚Äù he also waxed in the two minute screed. ‚ÄúN‚Äìs better not act up.‚Äù
item.author: Steven Vago
